DOC.HEAD: Bechtel Wins Piece Of Tokyo Airport Project
DOC.TEXT: Bechtel Group Inc. said it has won its first construction contract in Japan by landing a ``significant'' role in the building of an $800 million terminal at Tokyo's Haneda Airport. The construction and engineering giant said Wednesday it will participate with nine Japanese companies in building the 3.1-million-square-foot terminal, which gets under way next month. The project is scheduled to be finished in late fiscal 1992. Bechtel, like other U.S. contractors, has been trying to get a foothold in the Japanese construction market. It beame the first American company to receive a construction license in Japan but until now has been limited to feasibility studies for bridges, airport terminals, geothermal plants and a golf course. Company officials insisted their role in the Haneda Airport project would be more than a token one, though they did not specify a dollar figure. ``Our role in this important project is a very significant one, definitely not window dressing,'' said John L. Moore Jr., a member of the Bechtel Group Inc.'s board of directors. ``We're going to have to pull our weight alongside our Japanese partners.'' Haneda Airport, near downtown Tokyo, has been used primarily for domestic flights since the opening of Narita Airport 11 years ago. The terminal is being built to handle Japan's fast-growing domestic air-travel business. The project is headed by Taisei Corp. and includes Overseas Bechtel Inc. as a major shareholder. Other firms in the venture are Kajima Corp., Shimizu Corp., Takenaka Komuten Co. Ltd., Ohbayayashi Corp., Tokyo Construction Co. Ltd., Toda Construction Co. Ltd., Sato Kogyo Co. Ltd., and JAL Construction Co. Ltd.
